items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message: River levels are falling but this alert remains in place as levels are forecast to rise again overnight and through tomorrow 08/02/2024 on the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook due to forecast rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the road at Reybridge. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 11:30 AM on 08/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Christchurch Harbour
items.message:
Tomorrow morning (07/02/2024), tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions.

However, no property flooding is expected.

The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Christchurch Harbour of 1.33 mAODN at 8:45 AM on 07/02/2024, which is 0.8 m above tide tables (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.)

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high in response to winter rainfall across the area. Levels are high but are currently falling slowly at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater.

The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels and levels will likely rise again following rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 09/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Salwarpe
Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, groundwater levels are high but falling slowly. In Preston Candover, levels have fallen by 6cm in the last week. At Old Alresford, levels have fallen by 9cm. We expect a small number of properties in each village to be affected by cellar flooding. Groundwater levels will be reducing the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire throughout the next 4 days, with the possibility of very heavy rain (up to 40mm) on Thursday 08/02/2024. If heavy rain affects the area over the next couple of weeks, cellar flooding will become more widespread, and internal property flooding could occur in Old Alresford and Preston Candover. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 14/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels at Lopcombe Corner are high but have fallen by 1.7m during the last week. At West Tytherley, the groundwater level has fallen by 13cm. In Pitton, there may still be some residual flood water on the roads as well as impacts to the sewerage system. In most other villages, we expect groundwater flooding impacts to no longer be occurring. From Tuesday 06/02/2024, unsettled weather is expected to return to Hampshire, with very heavy rain (up to 60mm) possible on Thursday 08/02/2024. If the heaviest rain affects the area, then it is possible that properties could experience cellar flooding in Nether Wallop, Pitton and West Tytherley. In Broughton, high river and groundwater levels could combine to affect property. Widespread road and land flooding, and increased impacts to the sewerage system are also possible. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. We will update this Flood Alert by 18:00 on Monday 12/02/2024.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 

River levels are high on the River Kennet following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Water is expected to remain on low lying land and roads over the coming days. The forecast is for showers today 07/02/2024 with persistent, heavy rain from the early hours of Thursday 08/02/2024. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and are likely to rise over the coming days in response to rainfall.   

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Exmoor Rivers
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message: The risk of flooding from the Exmoor rivers has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. Further rainfall is forecast overnight Wednesday into Thursday and Flood Alerts may need to be issued.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels remain high but are falling at the Llanymynech river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. River levels at the Cae Howel river gauge continue to rise. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 3.73m at 2:45am on Wednesday, 07/02/24; Cae Howel 3.9m to 4.2m Wednesday, 07/02/24.
We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday, 08/02/24. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. Rivers may rise again.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 4pm on 07/02/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Arrow in Herefordshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: North Somerset area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, North Somerset, Somerset
floodArea.riverOrSea: Congresbury Yeo, Cheddar Yeo, River Axe, River Banwell

items.message: Little if any rain is forecast for the remainder of today. However, this Flood Alert may be reissued due to rainfall forecast overnight.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.

River levels have risen overnight on the Ginge Brook following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today 07/02/2024, especially in the Steventon area. Water is expected to remain on and around low lying land and roads over the coming days. The forecast is for showers today 07/02/2024 with persistent, heavy rain from the early hours of Thursday 08/02/2024.  Levels are very sensitive to further rainfall and are likely to rise again in response to forecast rainfall this week. 

We are monitoring the situation. Please report any blockages to the Environment Agency on 0800 80 70 60. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Chew catchment

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, North Somerset, Somerset
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Chew, Chew Stoke Stream, Winford Brook

items.message:
River levels are falling but are forecast to rise again on the River Chew, Winford Brook, Chew Stoke Stream due to rainfall forecast overnight and tomorrow 08/02/2024. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Chew, Winford Brook, Chew Stoke Stream, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the fords on Mill Lane and Pilgrims Way in Chew Stoke and The Batch and Dumpers Lane in Chew Magna.. River levels are forecast to rise at the Chew Magna Outlet,  Chew Stoke, and Compton Dando gauge. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 11:30 AM on 08/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels continue to rise at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is imminent. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.
We expect river levels to remain high for several days. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 4pm on 07/02/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Groundwater is high, within 80 cm of the surface in communities of the Lavant valley, but has been slowly falling. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Small amounts of water could still affect some basements. Showers are forecast Wednesday, with rain throughout much of Thursday and into Friday 09/02/2024. Over half a month's rain is forecast, between 40 and 60mm. Surface water will affect roads. Groundwater is expected to rise in communities through to mid February, but not rising as high as it has been previously this winter. Groundwater will remain close to the surface and minor flood impacts affecting the sewage network could continue through to March. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 11/02/2024

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: Groundwater levels in Twyford and Hensting are high but falling slowly. We expect a small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting to be affected by cellar flooding. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire throughout the next 4 days, with the possibility of very heavy rain (up to 40mm) on Thursday 08/02/2024. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will rise, Hensting Lane will continue to be affected by flood water, and flows in the ditch on Hazeley Road will increase. An increased number of properties could be affected by cellar flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 14/02/2024.

items.description: River Leam and River Itchen
items.message:
River levels are continuing to rise at the Kites Hardwick gauge as a result of the rainfall yesterday evening (06/02/2024). Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today (07/02/2024). We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.
There is no further rainfall forecast today (07/02/2024), however there is further – potentially heavy – further rainfall tomorrow (08/02/2024).
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated later today (07/02/2024), or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 7th February 2024.  This is due to last night's rainfall and the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system.  We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.  Levels will fall as water drains out, but frontal rainfall is forecast Thursday and Friday which may keep levels high a while longer.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Thursday 8th February 2024.

items.description: Middle Exe area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Exe, River Batherm, River Lowman, River Haddeo

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Exe has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. Further rainfall is forecast overnight Wednesday into Thursday and Flood Alerts may need to be issued.

items.description: River Wye in Herefordshire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Old Wye Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 07/02/24. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. The footpath on the North River bank in Hereford and King Georges playing fields start to flood. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at 2.56m this morning, Bredwardine predicted 4.3m to 4.6m, Belmont 4.2m to 4.5m and Old Wye Bridge 3.8m to 4.1m all on Wednesday afternoon, Mordiford 4.2m to 4.4m this evening, 07/02/24, Ross on Wye 3.7m to 3.9m overnight, 08/02/24. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to rise again as a result.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 4pm on 07/02/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: This alert remains in place as levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck and the River Hull due to recent prolonged rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Levels on Roam Drain are falling slowly but remain very high. Areas most at risk are around the rivers and drains between Frodingham Bridge and the Wilfholme area, including low-lying land around Hempholme. Our pumping stations are operating to reduce levels, however water levels will remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Wednesday 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.
River levels have risen on the River Pang following heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected over the coming days. The forecast is for showers today 07/02/2024 with persistent, heavy rain from the early hours of Thursday 08/02/2024.  River levels are already high, due to high groundwater levels, and remain sensitive to rainfall. Levels are expected to stabilise through today but are likely to rise again in response to Thursday's rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Frome in Herefordshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences. 
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Upper Avon and tributaries
items.message:
River levels will rise on the Upper Hampshire Avon due to today's rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Hampshire Avon.

Flooding is possible at tributaries between Upavon and Salisbury from 6:00 AM on 07/02/2024.

Further heavy rainfall is forecast from 08/02/2024. River levels are high and forecast to rise further.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Bourne Valley are high but falling. We expect that properties in Upton and Hurstbourne Tarrant are experiencing ongoing cellar flooding. Sewerage network and septic tank impacts are expected to be ongoing throughout the valley. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire throughout the next 4 days, with the possibility of very heavy rain (up to 40mm) on Thursday 08/02/2024. If heavy rain affects the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels will rise again, flows on the road in Upton will increase, and more properties in the valley will be affected by cellar flooding. It is possible that some properties could experience internal ground floor flooding. We have deployed flood barriers in St Mary Bourne to help manage flood risk and continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 14/02/2024.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels continue to rise at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following recent heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defenses.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 4pm on 07/02/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Exe area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Exe has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. Further rainfall is forecast overnight Wednesday into Thursday and Flood Alerts may need to be issued.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but stablising following winter rainfall across the area at our Hodcott observation borehole near West Ilsley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 09/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Aldbourne Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the Winter rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole at Water Acre in the Aldbourne Valley. The level is currently stable. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the next few weeks and levels remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 09/02/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Teme

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but continuing to drop slowly at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Upper Og Valley following winter rainfall across the area. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Levels are currently falling slowly but levels at this site are sensitive to individual rainfall events and will likely rise again following rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 09/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Tamar
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible tonight, Wednesday 7th February and into tomorrow morning. River levels remain high following heavy rainfall last night. Patchy rain is forecast over the daytime on Wednesday, with a weather front bringing more widespread and heavy rainfall overnight and into Thursday morning. River levels are expected to peak by 2pm tomorrow afternoon. Flooding to low-lying land and roads close to the river is possible. The main areas of concern are Tamarstone and Crowford Bridge. No flooding to properties is currently forecast.   

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Lilbourne gauge as a result of the rainfall yesterday evening (06/02/2024). Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today (07/02/2024). We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.
There is no further rainfall forecast today (07/02/2024), however there is further – potentially heavy – further rainfall tomorrow (08/02/2024).
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning (07/02/2024), or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message: Groundwater levels in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne are high but falling slowly. At our borehole in Kings Somborne, levels have fallen by 17cm in the last week. Isolated properties in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne may still be pumping water out of their cellars. Tankering of sewerage is ongoing. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire for the rest of this week, with very heavy rain (up to 60mm) possible on Thursday 08/02/2024. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will rise again and an increased number of properties may experience cellar flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 13/02/2024.

items.description: River Lambourn from Upper Lambourn to Great Shefford
items.message:
Further property flooding is not expected.

River levels on the River Lambourn are high following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Further flooding of property is not expected but flooding of roads and low lying land may continue today 07/02/2024, especially in the Eastbury area. The forecast is for showers today with persistent, heavy rain from the early hours of Thursday 08/02/2024. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and may rise again over the coming days in response to forecast rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water and be aware of flooded roads, do not drive through floodwater. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.

A flood warning remains in in force for the Upper River Lambourn at Eastbury. 
River levels on the Lambourn and its tributaries have risen overnight in response to heavy rainfall.  Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 07/02/2024. The forecast is for showers today with persistent, heavy rain from the early hours of Thursday 08/02/2024.  River levels are high due to high groundwater levels and remain sensitive to rainfall. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days and levels may rise again this week in response to forecast rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels remain high and are forecast to rise on the Bristol Avon and Semington Brook due to rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.. Further rainfall is forecast overnight and tomorrow morning 08/02/2024. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 11:30 AM on 08/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bishops Sutton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bishops Sutton remain high but have been falling very slowly over the last week. Minor impacts to septic tanks are expected to be ongoing. Residual flood water may be affecting roads such as the B3047. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire for the rest of this week, with very heavy rain (up to 40mm) possible on Thursday 08/02/2024. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will rise again, increased impacts to roads and septic tanks could occur, and a small number of properties in Bishops Sutton could experience cellar flooding within the next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 13/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover remain very high. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw, Hatherden, Penton Grafton and Penton Mewsey. Ongoing flooding impacts are expected to be impacting Deacon and Down Road in Kimpton, the main road in Penton Grafton, and the road from Biddesden to Appleshaw. Sewerage system impacts are expected in most villages. Surface water flooding risk continues in Thruxton. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire for the rest of this week, with very heavy rain (up to 40mm) possible on Thursday 08/02/2024. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will rise again, and more significant impacts to cellars, roads and sewerage networks are possible. In Hatherden, isolated properties may experience internal property flooding. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 13/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high but continue to fall slowly. Flows in the Chalton and Idsworth Lavants are reducing. We expect a small number of properties to be experiencing cellar flooding, and sewerage network impacts. Residual flood water may be affecting roads in the area. Dry weather is forecast from today (01/02/2024) to Monday (05/02/2024). Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling, and flooding impacts will slowly improve. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday 08/02/2024.

items.description: The River Burn from Southgate and Waterden to Burnham Thorpe
items.message: This message has been issued because of the continued flood risk to homes and businesses today, Wednesday 7th February 2024. River levels remain higher than normal in response to high groundwater levels following the rainfall this winter.  Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas in South Creake and Burnham Thorpe, including parts of the B1355. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time following last night's rainfall. The rest of today will be dry with no significant rainfall, but we are expecting two fronts of heavy rainfall, beginning Thursday morning, and overnight into Friday, and we may see levels rise in response. We will update this message when we get more confidence in the forecast. Flood water is dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk. We are monitoring the situation closely.  We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Thursday 8th February 2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bramdean and Cheriton are high but falling slowly. At Cheriton Wood, the level has fallen by 20cm in the last week. We expect isolated properties in Cheriton are being affected by cellar flooding. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire throughout the next 4 days, with the possibility of very heavy rain (up to 40mm) on Thursday 08/02/2024. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will rise and impacts to septic tanks will increase. Properties in Bramdean may experience cellar flooding in the next couple of weeks if heavy rain continues to be recorded. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 14/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Alton area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but slowly falling at our Farringdon borehole near Alton following a period of settled weather. However groundwater levels remain above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to the saturated ground and levels may start to increase again as we receive further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 13/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hursley are high but have fallen by 31cm in the last week. Widespread cellar flooding and impacts to the sewerage system are expected to be ongoing. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire for the rest of this week, with very heavy rain (up to 40mm) possible on Thursday 08/02/2024. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will rise again and internal ground floor flooding may occur to isolated properties within the next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 13/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high but falling very slowly. At our borehole in Oakley, the level has fallen by 10cm in the last week. We expect properties in Deane to be experiencing cellar flooding. Groundwater springflows are impacting land and roads. Septic tanks are struggling to operate properly. Unsettled weather is expected to affect Hampshire for the rest of this week, with very heavy rain (up to 40mm) possible on Thursday 08/02/2024. If very heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will rise again and it is possible that the access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) will need to be closed within the next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 13/02/2024.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message:
This warning remains in place as river levels in the upper River Hull catchment remain high following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and its tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill, including Roam Drain. We are operating pumps in the area and continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action and avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Wednesday 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hambledon are high but continue to fall. At Whitedale Farm, levels have fallen by 3.6m in the last week. We expect a small number of properties on Lower West Street to be affected by cellar flooding. Groundwater is likely to still be affecting the sewerage system. Dry weather is forecast from today (31/01/2024) until Sunday (04/02/2024). Groundwater levels in Hambledon are expected to continue falling, and flood impacts will slowly improve during this time. If further dry weather is forecast, we may remove this Flood Alert next week. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group and are monitoring the forecast. Please remain prepared for further flooding impacts this winter as groundwater levels remain sensitive to heavy rainfall. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 07/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Newmarket
items.message: Groundwater levels are holding steady in this area and may remain responsive to any further rainfall. This message applies to areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message in 7 days time, by 11:00am Wednesday 14th February.

items.description: Nailbourne and Little Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message: River levels remain high on the Little Stour and Nailbourne as of Monday 5th February 2024. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along the River Nailbourne around Bekesbourne, and areas along the Little Stour around Littlebourne. Flooding of property is not currently expected. Please avoid driving or walking through floodwater. Prolonged rainfall is currently forecast from late Tuesday 6th February at least until Friday 9 February. This is likely to result in increased flows and levels. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday 7th February 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: Groundwater levels in East Kent remain very high and are expected to remain high until Spring 2024. The Alkham Bourne and the Nailbourne between Lyminge and Littlebourne are flowing. Flow in the Little Stour between Littlebourne and Stourmouth is reducing slightly, due to low rainfall since mid January. Localised flooding may still affect low-lying land, roads, and water infrastructure in and around the Elham Valley, Alkham, and Petham. Other communities in East Kent may also be impacted. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. No further rainfall is currently forecast until Wednesday 7 February. We are monitoring the situation and are working with local authorities and communities with the deployment of temporary defences, such as Canterbury City Council’s temporary defences in Barham. Our staff are maintaining and clearing key structures. This message will be updated by Thursday 8 February 2024, or as the situation changes. Search ‘Kent Groundwater Situation’ on gov.uk.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few weeks by flooding from groundwater.

Groundwater levels in this area are rising slowly and we expect to see them continuing to rise if we receive further rainfall over the next few weeks. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 09/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high but falling very slowly at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm near Great Shefford in response to the winter rainfall across the area. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater. Groundwater levels are currently steady, but could rise further if we see persistent or heavy rain. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 09/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is high, and close to the surface, but has been slowly falling at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will likely continue through to late February, with springs affecting fields and small amounts of water on roads including Stoughton main road and the road from East Marden. Groundwater could affect a small number of properties close to the village green Stoughton and possibly basements or near the ground floor of properties in Walderton too. Showers are forecast Wednesday, with rain throughout much of Thursday and into Friday 09/02/2024. Over half a month's rain is forecast, between 40 and 60mm. Surface water will affect roads. Groundwater is expected to rise in communities through to mid February, but not rising as high as it has been previously this winter. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 11/02/2024

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Churn as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this morning 07/02/2024, especially in the Cerney Wick area. Showers are forecast today before heavy, persistent rain moves in tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high today and levels may rise further in response to forecast rainfall later this week. We are monitoring the situation and our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 7th February 2024. This is due to last night's rainfall and the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay. Levels will fall as water drains out, but frontal rainfall forecast on Thursday and Friday may keep levels high a while longer. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Thursday 8th February.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Ray as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this morning 07/02/2024, especially in the Grendon Underwood area. Showers are forecast today before heavy, persistent rain moves in tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue rising through this morning. We are monitoring the situation and our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ock from Watchfield to Abingdon, and also the Letcombe Brook at Wantage, Grove and East Hanney
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Ock as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this morning 07/02/2024, especially in the Stanford in the Vale area. Showers are forecast today before heavy, persistent rain moves in tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue rising through this morning. We are monitoring the situation and our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to heavy rainfall last night. Flooding is possible over the next 24 to 48 hours. Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook.  Further rain is expected over the next 24 hours which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 6pm today, 7 February 2024.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 7 February 2024.  This is due to last night's rainfall and the natural tide locking effect. Tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. Levels will fall as water drains out, but frontal rainfall forecast Thursday and Friday may keep levels high a while longer. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Thursday 8 February.

items.description: River Torridge (Lower) from Dolton to Bideford, including Taddiport and Weare Giffard
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is expected on Wednesday morning (7th February).
Heavy rain has been falling in the River Torridge area, causing the River Torridge to rise.
Properties and low lying areas in Taddiport (properties around Taddiport Bridge, Sewage Treatment Works and B3227) and Weare Giffard (riverside properties and roads), will start to flood first from around 08:00am on Wednesday. River levels will be at their highest between 7am and 1pm.
Flood waters may be deep and fast flowing in these areas. Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your local surroundings.
We are closely monitoring the situation, and this message will be updated Wednesday afternoon, or if the situation changes.

items.description: East Somerset Rivers

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
River levels have risen on the River Brue due to last night’s heavy rainfall.

Areas most at risk include the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road. Overtopping is forecast from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay.  The River Brue is forecast to be bankfull upstream of Bruton Dam with field flooding likely.

Some rain is forecast today, with heavy rain possible tomorrow. We expect river levels to fall later today but to rise in response again on Thursday.
 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 12 noon, Thursday, 08/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to heavy rainfall last night. Flooding is possible over the next 24 to 48 hours. Areas most at risk are those around the River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield.  Further rain is expected over the next 24 hours which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences and clearing weed screens. We will update this message by 6pm today, 7 February 2024

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Walton gauge as a result of the rainfall yesterday evening (06/02/2024). Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today (07/02/2024).
There is no further rainfall forecast today (07/02/2024), however there is further – potentially heavy – rainfall tomorrow (08/02/2024).
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated later today (07/02/2024), or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning, 07/02/24.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 this afternoon, 07/02/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tributaries on the Upper River Thames above Cricklade

floodArea.riverOrSea: Flagham Brook, Swill Brook, Hankerton Brook, Hykemeres Stream, Derry Brook, River Key

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Key as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this morning 07/02/24, especially in the Purton Stoke area. Showers are forecast today before heavy, persistent rain moves in tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high today and levels may rise further in response to forecast rainfall later this week. Our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 07/02/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Torridge area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible early Wednesday 7 February.
Heavy rain has been falling in the River Torridge area, which is causing river levels to rise.
Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river is possible, and flood warnings may be required.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Wednesday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Winford Brook at Chew Magna
The Rivers Deben and Lark
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Wednesday 7 February 2024. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in response to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas on the Deben from Debenham to Ufford, including Framsden, Earl Soham, Easton, Glevering and Wickham Market, and on the Rivers Lark and Finn around Witnesham, Tuddenham St Martin, Playford and Grundisburgh. The forecast is for further rainfall throughout Thursday and Friday. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow, Thursday 8 February 2024.

items.description: The Rivers Wid and Can
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Wednesday 7 February 2024. We are currently seeing higher river levels than normal in response to recent rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. The forecast is for further rainfall throughout Thursday and Friday, to which the river will remain responsive. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update this message tomorrow, Thursday 8 February 2024.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Thame as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today 07/02/24, especially in the Thame area. Showers are forecast today before heavy, persistent rain moves in tomorrow. We expect river levels to remain high today and levels may rise further in response to forecast rainfall later this week. Our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 07/02/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Great Ouse in Cambridgeshire from Brampton to Earith
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to rainfall over the last 24 hours. Flooding is possible from now until tomorrow morning. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Brampton to Earith, including Back Brook, Hall Green Brook, Parsons Drove Drain, Swavesey Drain and Wadsbys Folly. Access to properties in Berry Lane, Godmanchester, may also be affected.  Whilst only light rain is expected today, further rainfall is expected tomorrow (Thursday) and Friday which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, 07/02/2024.

items.description: Middle River Great Ouse in Milton Keynes, Bedford Borough and Central Bedfordshire
items.message: River levels are rising steadily in response to rainfall over the last 24 hours. Flooding is possible from now until tomorrow morning, 8th February 2024. Areas most at risk are around the River Great Ouse from Newport Pagnell to Roxton. Whilst only light rain is expected today, further rainfall is expected tomorrow (Thursday 8th February) and Friday which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, 7th February 2024.

items.description: River Avon in Worcestershire
items.message:
River levels are currently rising at the Evesham and Bredon river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. 

Predicted peaks:- 

Evesham, 1.8m to 2.1m Wednesday evening, 07/02/2024; Bredon, 1.5m to 1.8m on Thursday morning, 08/02/2024.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. Additional rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours which is expected to keep river levels elevated, and may cause levels to rise again beyond the current predicted levels later this week, and into the weekend.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
  
This message will be updated by 5:00pm today, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Upper Pound and Mythe Bridge river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore.

Predicted peaks:-
Upper Pound, 2.7m to 3.0m on Thursday morning, 08/02/2024. Mythe, 2.5m to 2.9m on Thursday morning, 08/02/2024.

We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. No flooding is expected at other gauge locations based on recent rain totals. Additional rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours which is expected to keep river levels elevated, and may cause levels to rise again beyond the current predicted peaks later this week, and into the weekend.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 5:00pm today, 07/02/2024, or as the situation changes.
